I was reading that Akiyama Kyusaku, the authority whose views on tsuba were=
 formative for both Torigoye and Sasano, evidently actually distinguished t=
suba made from steel hagane =E9=8B=BC from tsuba made from iron tetsu =E9=
=89=84.    Steel tsuba were said to have been originally reddish in color, =
but after a century took on the purplish-black color found in Old Owari tsu=
ba and those made by the Higo Hayashi family.  Iron tsuba were said to be m=
erely black, and to appear soft by comparison.   

I have heard, and read, =
a great deal of discussion about the importance of the quality of the tsuba=
's plate, but I have not heard much about the differences between iron and =
steel tsuba.  Do the experts of today make that distinction?
